text:
There's no question there's
great use cases of technology,

but the opportunities to really be
disruptive within the US K-12 system
are very few.

Outside of the fringes on
both the left and right,

there's actually lots
of agreement in the 80%

around the education that
we want our kids to have.

15% of colleges in the United
States have closed or merged.

Only a third of the public believes
in the promise of higher ed right now.
I think we can be much more relevant,

keep up with the pace of
change in meaningful ways,

and not sort of fall back on the old
pedagogical models that we've had.

And I think we're gonna be able
to use AI to more rapidly spin up

educational programs alongside
those work-based experiences

to help make sure people don't
have gaps in their learning.

Lifelong learning won't
just be a buzz phrase;

it's going to be a way of how
we work and exist in society.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
My name is Michael Horn.

I'm a lecturer at the Harvard
Graduate School of Education

and the co-founder of the
Clayton Christensen Institute.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

There are no shortage of hot takes
about the impact AI is going to have on
business and society right now.

My own take is like anything
else, it's not normative.

It's how we use it,
the business models we put it into

and what we ask of it,
that's ultimately going to shape it.
But I will say I'm an optimist

and I think ultimately it's
going to put much more power

in the hands of
individuals to be creative,

to imagine things that they
couldn't have otherwise done

and create all sorts of new
businesses, organizations –

things that I think will be disruptive
but will ultimately empower individuals
and humanity over the long run.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Clay Christensen,
who is a long time faculty member at

the Harvard Business School, was known as
the father of disruptive innovation theory.

When we published
Disrupting Class in 2008,

we were really optimistic
that technology,

properly implemented in
new models of learning,

could really personalize learning, to be
sort of a tutor for every single child.

I think what we've seen
in the years since is that

there's no question there's
great use cases of technology,

but the opportunities to really be
disruptive within the US K-12 system

are very few, because there's not a
lot of what Clay would have called

non consumption, areas where the
alternative is truly nothing at all,
in a way that really reinvents the system.

I think we were right about a
lot of the fundamental precepts,

which is that we have an educational
model that was never built

to optimize the way
students, individuals learn.

It was built to sort them
out at various intervals.

It was built not for the knowledge
economy but for the industrial economy.

We really need to disrupt that model
if we hope to leverage everyone's
full human potential.
I think we were right on all of that.

I think where we were wrong was we maybe
assumed some of the properties that AI

frankly, is bringing to the fore
that didn't exist back then,

that there would be systems that
would learn from themselves over time

and take in data from how
individual students were doing

and improve in ways that the education
technology of that era just weren't doing.

And I think we were right that we needed
to fundamentally reinvent the model.

Like, technology is not good enough by
itself to fundamentally create change;
it's how it's used that really matters.

But I think we were guilty
perhaps of some magical thinking,

that somehow public schools
that had been around for decades

could just naturally incorporate
that and make those really big shifts

in their classrooms and sort of
overthrow decades of regulation

to make the changes to a
truly student centered system
in the time period that we hoped for.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

In 2011, Clay Christensen was out
in front of an audience and said,

“50% of colleges will close or merge
or go bankrupt over the next decade.”
As we dug into it a little bit more,

really it's more like 25% of
colleges and universities are running

business models that just don't work and
they're going to need to close or merge.

I think as we even dug into it more
deeply, we said, really,
this is a two decade change.

It's driven by demographic declines
in the wake of the Great Recession.

It's driven by a model
that keeps adding cost,
but can't possibly charge people more.

And it's driven by a model where there
are starting to become substitutes

in how we get our college educations
and upskilling in the world of work.

What we're now seeing is that
over the last 10 years alone,

15% of colleges in the United
States have closed or merged.

Over the past year, almost one
college every single week has closed.

In public colleges and universities, we've
seen whole systems consolidate in dramatic

fashion in the states of Pennsylvania,
Georgia, Connecticut, Wisconsin, and more.

And so we've really seen
that we have overbuilt supply

for dwindling demand over the past many
years, and it's coming to roost right now.

The really interesting thing,
I think on top of that,

is that right now we're at peak
demographics of the numbers of students
graduating from American high schools.
It's about to decline precipitously,

because starting in 2008
people had fewer babies.

So we have too many seats in
colleges for 18-year-olds

with not nearly enough
18-year-olds coming out;

at the same time that a lot of
people are skeptical about the value

of an ever more expensive
college or university experience

and not sure, do I really get a return
on the other side that makes it worth it?

Under that weight,
the 15% that have already closed,

I think it's easy to imagine that we get
to 25, 40% over the next five, six years.

Here's the thing, which is if you're at
a place like Harvard or Yale or Stanford

or the state flagship schools, or the
Notre Dames of the world, you're fine.

There's so much demand for limited
seats at those universities,
they've been able to charge high prices.

They make a lot of money, frankly,
from the research grants that come in.

They're really research first
institutions in many cases.

They're incredibly important to
the economies that surround them.

Those sorts of institutions
are going to be fine.

It's really this soft middle tier where
these institutions are very expensive,

the expenditures underlying
them continue to go up,
they don't have strong brand names,

and they have trouble attracting students
beyond 50, 75 miles of where they live.

A stat that might surprise you is a decade
ago, 40% of colleges and universities

enrolled fewer than 1,000
students in this country.

That's where,
when we see this hollowing out,

there are 4,000 some odd colleges
and universities in this country.

That's where the hollowing
out is really happening.

It's not happening at the elite ends
of our American university system.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

As AI comes in, how is it going to change
the existence of colleges and universities?

I think if we're totally honest,
we have no real clue yet.

AI is still searching for product
market fit in higher education,

as Cal Newport, the noted computer
scientist at Georgetown, said recently.

But I think we can see a few
things are starting to change.

A lot of institutions are going to be
able to use AI in what we would call

sustaining innovations, to improve
the way they currently serve students.
So student success measures,

to take in data and respond
much quicker to their needs,

to frankly create a more
frictionless environment for students
who are coming into college and university.

The other piece where AI is making
an immediate impact is in research.

It's helping a lot of faculty
members do research quicker,

come up with different hypotheses,
test them in novel ways,

crank out new papers and things
of that nature much faster,
maybe much more readable.

In terms of teaching and learning,
I think the jury is still out.

My own hypothesis is that we're
probably going to see a wave of

new colleges and universities,
or new post secondary institutions,

apprenticeship programs, boot camps,
things like that, that are powered by AI,

that create maybe more personalized
teaching and learning experiences

than we could Have otherwise imagined 
and it'll be really interesting to see

what the impact on the market
is of those innovations.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

There's no question, right now
we're just at the beginning tip of
AI changing the way we work.

My sense is, over the next couple
years, the changes will be modest,

but over the next 10 years, 15 years,
they're going to be pretty dramatic.

Already it's said that
people in technical fields,

their skills depreciate
basically every four years.

So you need to be constantly
upskilling and re-skilling.

I think AI is just going to
accelerate a lot of those trends.

The impact of that on
colleges and universities,
I think at least two seismic impacts.

Number one, the need to be
upskilling much more frequently

throughout our lives is
going to become paramount.

And so having short burst,
quick programs that we can just

duck in, get more skills,
duck back out of into the workforce,

much more seamless experience
of work and learning,

I think are going to be really
important, but also huge opportunities

for colleges and universities
looking to serve more students

because adults,
all of us in the world of work,

we're going to just need to be learning
much more throughout our lives.

Lifelong learning won't
just be a buzz phrase,

it's going to be a way of how
we work and exist in society,

and colleges and universities
have a big role to play there.

I think the second thing
that is going to change

is make experiential learning much more
important to the learning experience.

If AI is changing how
we work really rapidly,

keeping up with those changes, codifying
them in say a textbook or an online course,
is going to be really hard.

The moment you do it, it's going to be
out of date six months, a year later.

But the more we can create really
experiential opportunities

for students to learn through cases,
through simulations, on the job,

things of that nature,
I think we can be much more relevant,

keep up with the pace of
change in meaningful ways,

and not sort of fall back on the old
pedagogical models that we've had.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

The substitute products coming
into the post secondary market,

the low cost alternatives,
are really growing pretty rapidly.

Google has its certificates,
so you can learn IT skills,

and not just certificates, but you can take
them online through any number of partners.

In the case of Coursera,
it serves literally millions and millions
of learners today.

It's not just Google, but you can
name any IT company at this point,
any tech company,

and they tend to have a training
program built around their ecosystem –
Facebook, Unity, you name it.

And so for technical skills,
I think in many ways,

the job of colleges and universities
would be, how do we provide a wrapper

around what they offer, so that people
don't just get the narrow technical skills

but they can get that
certificate, that mastery,

and also something bigger
with pedagogy and things that

a college or university
should be specializing in,

about how to actually teach and convey this
information so people actually learn it?
That's I think the first thing.

The second piece of it is colleges
and universities, historically anyway,

aren't just interested in the
transmitting of technical skills,

but also how you put
that in a deeper context,

what's often called the soft skills
of learning, the critical thinking,

communication, working with others
through collaboration, things like that.

I think colleges and universities
not just saying that,

but really creating authentic places where
people can collaborate and learn together
through these different technical paradigms

I think is a place where they
can really add a lot of value

to the stuff that we don't
know how to measure well,

but we know is really important
for human flourishing.

In higher education outside
of colleges and universities,
I think we're at this moment where

we're starting to see new
forms of learning pop up.

A lot of these are going to
be work-based experiences.

So apprenticeships are becoming
a much bigger point of emphasis.

People and employers are thinking,
how can we leverage these

to educate the future workforce
without a degree, perhaps,

but make sure we get really good
individuals coming into these jobs
to power our future success?

A lot of people are looking
at work-based degrees.

We have an alum of the
school, Mallory Dwindle,

who is building work-based
degree programs.

So you get the best of the degree,
but you get really practical experience
on the ground

and far more affordable because it doesn't
cost a lot of money to educate people,
and they can be earning money in a job

while they are learning as a
core part of the experience.

I think we're going to see a lot of
these alternatives to traditional college

make much bigger headway
in the years ahead.

What we really have right now in the
economy, I think, is a signaling problem;

that traditional degrees have
never been a perfect proxy for

this person's ready for this particular
job, but they're breaking down faster.

And what's more, when we need
technically skilled people in jobs,
and frankly, even more technically skilled

because a lot of entry level
roles are disappearing right now.

People are going to need
more technical skills

but they don't necessarily
have degrees to get those.

And so these alternatives to the
traditional college experience

that are much more
ensconced in work itself,

embedded with the skills and experiences
people need to really succeed,
I think is going to be the future.

AI is going to sort of
accelerate that in two ways.

One, because the changing nature
of work is going to accelerate,

having people on the ground with you,
actually working on the problems,

getting real experiences,
understanding what the job entails,
and building the appropriate skills,

I think that's going to be more
important, not less, in the future.

And I think we're going to be able
to use AI to more rapidly spin up

educational programs alongside
those work-based experiences,

to help make sure people don't
have gaps in their learning,

or have the right technical foundation
to be able to be great at those jobs.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I think the narrative around everyone needs
a degree is already starting to shift.

I think it's being
driven by a few things.

Number one, many, many, many families
across the country are looking at

colleges and universities and becoming
much more discerning customers.

They're saying, roughly 38% don't complete
a four year program within six years.

They take on a lot of debt,
and there's no return on the other side
if you get a lot of debt but no degree.

A lot of them are looking and saying,
half of those who do graduate
go into jobs that don't require the degree.
And what the research is telling us is,

if you start in a job that
doesn't require a degree,

five years later odds are very high
that you're going to still be in a job
that does not require a degree.

At the same time,
companies are starting to question,

do I need to require
degrees for all these roles?
What's the real value of that?

And so they're dropping
degree requirements,

although they are still using
degrees often to hire in practice.

So we'll see how that shakes
out in the years ahead.

But here's the other piece of it
that I think is really interesting.

Gen Z coming up right now through the
end of high school and graduating,

more and more of them are going to
vocational programs instead of college.
More and more of them are saying,

“I'm going to take a gap year and figure
out, is college really right for me?”

More and more of them are seeing the
shortages, not just in the skilled trades,

but also in tech fields and the like,
and saying,

“Huh, maybe there's a
different path into those.”

So you couple that with an environment
where only a third of the public

believes in the promise
of higher ed right now,

and it's not just among Republicans
that the confidence is collapsing,

I think Democrats, about 50%
believe in college at the moment.

What I think you're seeing though,
is a shift in how both parties

are actually thinking and talking
about post-secondary education,
so anything after high school.

Which is to say,
when President Obama was in office,

this notion of everyone needs some college,
everyone needs some sort of degree,

was very ascendant,
in the Democratic Party in particular.

And now I think you see a shift,
where both Vice President Harris

and President,
now President-elect Trump,

were talking about these
college alternatives.

There's real bipartisan agreement that
having a system of apprenticeships

that's not just for say, HVAC and
plumbing, but also IT and salesforce jobs

and Facebook marketing and things of
that nature, and healthcare, on and on,

could be a real part of our education
and workforce systems in this country.

In many ways, while we see a big
departure right now among the population,

I actually think in an interesting way
among policymakers we see some convergence

to saying, we ought to look at
these alternatives and think about

how they promised pathways
for all Americans,

regardless of what
really lights their fire.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Obviously, COVID and the pandemic
were brutal on a lot of families
in K-12 school systems.

But I do think that there was
an interesting silver lining
in creating more room for innovation.
Because while a lot of school systems,

I think they were prisoner to
their one-size-fits-all mentality

about how we educate and serve students
and families from very different

walks of life and very different
learning needs at different times,
what it did was empower parents to say,

“My neighborhood public school isn't
the only way to get an education.”

So I think what we've seen is that
education is getting a lot less linear.

My own take is that disruption happens
when there's either non consumption,

or people are over served
by the existing system.
You might say,

“Come on, Michael, how are people
possibly overserved by our K-12 schools?

All we read about is how they're
chronically underperforming or achieving.”

But I think for a lot of
families, they're like,

“I don't really care
about the football team,”

or, “I don't care about
this set of services,”
or, “I don't need that.”

And so this micro school community
that's extremely personalized,

really rebuilding community in the way I
think our public schools originally did,

and that are publicly funded in some
states, now up to 12 universally so,
I think for many families and students

that's creating a really
interesting innovation pathway
to drive disruptive innovation

and drive personalization in
some really interesting ways.

I think the question will be this, do we
move to this fully alternative system,

or even better, do our public
school districts start to say,

“Huh, we could do that too. We can create
alternative pathways in our own districts,

and create micro schools,
schools within schools,

different schooling hubs, if you will,
where we really bring the best of community

with personalization to empower people
through many different pathways.”

In some ways, I'm actually more
optimistic than I've ever been before,

because I think parents are
really voting with their feet.

Educators, interestingly enough,
are most of the entrepreneurs behind these
innovative forms of schooling.

And together, I wonder,
will they create a bigger shift

that's more student
centered in the long run,

and more schools and more
school systems will say,
“You know what? We can do that too.”
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I think there's been a generation of
kids, frankly, continuing right now

into the school systems that
COVID just was devastating for.

I think a lot of students today are
still extremely disengaged in school.

We know enrollment in urban
school districts has plummeted
and continues to plummet.

We know that chronic absenteeism
remains incredibly high,

and when you go into schools a lot of
places they just aren't very engaged.
I think rather than focus on the systems

and the schools and the
traditional structures,

we need to be much more mindful of how
each individual reconnects, reengages.

It's something that's
really motivating for them.

If that's sort of the
entry level principle,

then hopefully we
can start to rebuild.
But gosh, there's just millions of kids.

You know, this is an enduring
fact of the pandemic,

that there's millions of people
who didn't go to college,

they didn't enter the workforce, and we
don't really know what they're doing.
How do we reengage those individuals,

I think is a really tricky
question for us right now.

We're in a moment right now where baby
boomers are leaving the workforce.
They're starting to retire.

And we know that employers
consistently report they cannot find
qualified people for large numbers of jobs.

So we have this really
weird moment in the economy

that's more than a passing moment,
which is that employers are keeping

job openings open for long periods of time,
really struggling to fill them.

People are remaining stuck
in work at the moment

that they're not necessarily
excited or passionate about,
but they're nervous if they quit,

and how will they change jobs
and find something different?

Then there's large numbers
of people who are disengaged,

not in the workforce at all, and frankly,
they don't count in the unemployment rate

because they're not
actively looking for work.
And so on one end, you could say,

well, okay, this is devastating
to the individual communities.

But I think it's devastating to
the American economy writ large.

I just think if we can reengage those
people who are on the sidelines with

short burst programs that are low risk,
that allow them to earn while they learn,

and get them reengaged with their
hands, with their minds, something,

we could unlock a lot of
growth in this country

that we're completely
discounting right now.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

What's always struck me about
the education at a place like

the Harvard Business School
for MBA students is that,
yes, you delve into the technical details,

how to build and read and analyze, say, a
financial model, but you never stop there.

You're always asking a
question in a case of,

what would you do with this
information if you were the CEO?

What would you do as a manager
confronted with this information?

What's the question you really
need to ask about this model?

And so the way I think about it with AI
is that our tools are going to change.

But I think for students, having an
underlying sense of the knowledge

underpinning those answers that
the models spit back at us,

is still going to be important
so we can interrogate them,
see where we agree or disagree,

see where we think there's
judgment calls involved.

The data is not going to tell me what
to do, because it's backward looking.

It's what's my theory of what
this data is starting to show me,

and where's the world going,
that I need to be preparing for.

And so being able to ask good
questions and have great theories

that allow you to act on the
information you know ahead of time,

I think is really going to be
critical for leaders of businesses
and society in the future.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
